thread.title_full: How to be a savvy shopper in six simple steps - Telegraph

author: Rachel Halliwell
title: How to be a savvy shopper in six simple steps
text: Discover more energy saving tips » 1 Resist discounts More than 75 per cent of us are encouraged to buy an item offered as a bargain, while a TV advert for the same product convinces only 3.5 per cent, according to the Debt Advisory Centre. 2 Plan Ahead Sales shopping is a brilliant way to save money. Find out when your favourite shops are having their sales. If you sign up to their newsletters you often get advance notice. 3 Collect codes Before you make a big purchase, check online which stores are offering discount codes. Newsletters often send out loyalty codes and money-off vouchers. 4 Shop off-season The same garden furniture you were looking at in spring can be up to 75 per cent cheaper as summer draws to an end and retailers make room for new stock. 5 Barter Haggling, whether it’s over the price of a dishwasher or the cost of a hotel room, can sometimes pay off. It might work only some of the time, but even if it doesn’t, it won’t cost you a thing. 6 Save, don’t borrow Sticking a bargain on a credit card could end up costing you more in interest than you saved on the purchase cost. If you’ve budgeted and saved for the things you need, you’ll have the cash ready to pay for them. Go figure £142 is wasted a year (or £9,159 over an average lifetime) by the average Brit buying sales items they never wear £1,770 would be put away after 10 years if you saved that £142 each year and it grew at 4 per cent a year 34 per cent of us get smart and start our Christmas shopping in the summer sales • Learn about smart meters and find out how you can save money and time to spend on the things you love.
